People have laughed and told me that I suck all my life 

I usually respond with some form of “alright I hear you - how do I fix this?”

About 50-80% will keep laughing and making jokes, but about 20% will be like, huh, you wanna get better? Really? Okay, well... https://t.co/1HIV6rGJUE
  [Quoting Tweet 1300347517675147264 (missing)]

1300353686644772865 [2020-08-31] @visakanv 💜 37 🔁 1
Some of my best friends, best opportunities, best experiences, best learnings etc have come from holding my ground and being earnest in the face of insults and criticism. People expect you to give up

Repeat after me, if you feel like it:

Life is hard, and full of rejection and failure.

But.

I will never be the one to count myself out.

I will never take up arms against myself.

I will never be the one to sabotage me.

I’m on my side and I root for me to succeed. https://t.co/Eo1Pk9g3et

1413343370118717440 [2021-07-09] @AskYatharth 💜 4
This made me cry.

I stopped reading [this is even before the Foreword] and took the hour off to reflect on just this.

“What is the real game?”
“It is a game in which the heart is entertained, the game in which you are entertained.”

Do not forget the game you are playing. https://t.co/SzXV35P39p

“Once you understand the principles . . . you will be able to quiet your mind, focus clearly, and /truly play the game/.”

What it means is every other time, we are not playing the game. https://t.co/zFhap6uHr2

1413345419468296192 [2021-07-09] @AskYatharth 💜 8 🔁 1
When we are demurring, or apologising, or fretting—we are not playing the game.

When we are anything but sunk, whole-heartedly advocating for ourselves—we are not playing the game.

We are playing a different game.

Called “Look at me and don’t judge me, please.” https://t.co/9HEOb0sfH5
  [Quoting @AskYatharth: The drama is a plea to show your authority figures you ARE doing something. Can’t they see??  Gosh, I get chills writing this, feeling into the truth of how I still do this to this day. https://t.co/DXF3Itu7tX]
↓

    "commit to self-love bc nobody will love you till you can" feels coercive & also plain wrong. 
    
    plus: self-love as a strategy to get other-love? what?
    
    meanwhile: "commit to self-love bc everybody wants to love everybody, and pragmatically not everyone has capacity" feels better

    @relic_radiation This is more of a statement about codependence, ie, high quality love exists in interdependence, when both parties love and protect themselves but choose to be dependent on the other for synergy, not out of need

not to dunk on or attack anybody else but, just reflecting on my own experience

if I let my fear of being excluded or intimidated as a child keep me out, I don't think I would have made it to adulthood

I was basically an alien outsider my whole life

https://t.co/BFp6PToQuM
  [Quoting @visakanv: let's play "spot the visa", it shouldn't take you more than 2-5 seconds each time. I'm like the opposite of Where's Waldo. Where's Visa? everyone knows where Visa is at all times, which also means that everyone knows if Visa is absent. I've never been able to hide, ever https://t.co/m55NbY4xf0]
↓
1424125550600232961 [2021-08-07] @visakanv 💜 18 🔁 2
like, I'm not saying, pretend you don't feel excluded, pretend you don't feel intimidated. those feelings are real. you can accept them. you can face them. you can acknowledge that you're terrified and then Do The Thing anyway

https://t.co/nHONsUtzuG
  [Quoting @visakanv: a wise older guy once said, "i learned in my 20s that me putting off something scary *always* led to things getting worse. so I cultivated the habit of throwing myself immediately into whatever scary bullshit came my way. it's my day-to-day horror meditation. AHHH!!!!"]
↓
1424126222284464132 [2021-08-07] @visakanv 💜 20 🔁 2
being ostracized, for eg – shunned, cast out – it can feel like literal death. it's mortifying. you may even actually throw up from shock, horror, disgust.

but, amazingly, as long as you remain resolute about making it to the next day, you'll find that you're still here. alive
↓
1424126778239422465 [2021-08-07] @visakanv 💜 17 🔁 1
rejection sucks. failure sucks. racism sucks. there's a lot of cruelty in the world, some of it completely innocuous, like a passing shower, and some of it directed straight at you, for reasons you might not understand in the moment, or ever.

and yet. the world spins on
↓

1742401720771354896 [2024-01-03] @visakanv 💜 1058 🔁 31 💬 1
wife and i were on a walk with our son and we witnessed an interesting conflict in another family unit. there was a wailing toddler asking her aunt(?) (cousin?) to carry her, and an older aunt(/grandma?) was insisting very forcefully that no!!, she must walk!!, dont be lazy!!!…
↓
1742401943841219023 [2024-01-03] @visakanv 💜 261 🔁 1
it looked like a difficult/sad/uncomfortable situation, no judging, but we discussed what we thought and how we would handle it if it were us, and here are my thoughts as follows
↓
1742402373103034517 [2024-01-03] @visakanv 💜 353 🔁 3
1. In the moment, it doesnt reaaaally matter whether the child walks or is carried. and thats not really what the conflict is about either. this is a proxy conflict, about connection vs independence, and kids (and adults!) need both
↓
1742402939564732790 [2024-01-03] @visakanv 💜 414 🔁 8
2. i always think its important to ask what the child is really asking, what the child is really anxious about. and in this case i think the fear is the annihilating collapse of the old world. this is a destruction of comfort. kid is making bids to ask “can i still be loved”
↓
1742403343383945236 [2024-01-03] @visakanv 💜 328 🔁 3
3. but the adults/caregivers are also anxious about the kid’s development. they dont want to coddle her, stifle her independence, leave her developmentally stunted.often the most cursed part is what theyre anxious sbout is the judgement of others. looking like bad/failed parents
↓
1742403796985323871 [2024-01-03] @visakanv 💜 504 🔁 7
4. when this plays out with my kid, and im sure it will, i would be careful to avoid making things so dramatic/binary. can you walk a little bit and then ill carry you a little bit? soothe him and love him if he’s distressed, but then cheerfully challenge him to grow
↓
1742404215203578078 [2024-01-03] @visakanv 💜 394 🔁 7
5. the tragedy here is a wretchedness spiral where the child’s anxiety about being cast out from love is spiraling together with the caregiver’s anxiety about failure to perform (their own as parent, and the child’s) into a yelling-screaming match where everything gets worse
↓
1742404565146997168 [2024-01-03] @visakanv 💜 300 🔁 7
6. i half-jokingly but earnestly pointed out to wife that this has parallels with sexual intimacy/performance for a couple. imagine getting mad at each other for failing to be aroused, excited, etc. imagine being mad at each other for seeking comfort. yelling will surely help lol
↓
1742405343521702275 [2024-01-03] @visakanv 💜 217 🔁 5
7. in all cases, if its not happening, its not happening, and trying to force it just makes everything worse. the problem isnt solved on the “playing field”, but off of it. in training, while socializing, away from the field. this does require spending time/effort communicating
↓
1742406028837445973 [2024-01-03] @visakanv 💜 321 🔁 24
8. the safer, more secure, attached, comfortable etc someone feels, the more confident they will be about taking risks, trying new things, etc. this isnt just for kids, this is for all of us. we need encouragement more than we need threats and ultimatums.
